conclusion: To determine if the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds, we need to analyze the v-t graph and its derivatives.
The v-t graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time. A straight line on this graph would indicate constant acceleration, while a curve indicates changing acceleration.
We are specifically concerned with the time interval from 1 second to 2 seconds.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity increases linearly, indicating constant positive acceleration.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity curve starts to level off, which means the rate of change of velocity (acceleration) is decreasing.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly, indicating constant negative acceleration.
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time, \(a = \frac{dv}{dt}\). The slope of the v-t graph gives the acceleration at any point in time.
At t = 1 second, the slope of the tangent to the curve is relatively steep.
As time progresses from 1 to 2 seconds, the tangent lines become less steep, indicating that the acceleration is decreasing over this interval.
